results.name: Matthew Riley
results.biography:
Matthew Riley is a web and interactive designer currently lecturing in Animation and Interactive Media at RMIT. Matthew has worked ona range of interactive, on-line and print projects with Drome Pty Ltd, Arts Victoria, Chunky Move, the University of Melbourne, RMIT and the Australian Interactive Media Industry Association amoung others.
Matthew Riley is a Melbourne based new-media artist and designer who works with video, web and interactive media.
He was awarded a Bachelors degree in Education and Fine Art at The University of Melbourne in 1996 before completing three years of post-graduate study in multimedia and animation at RMIT, an Advanced Diploma in Electronic Design and Interactive Media (EDIM) and a Graduate Diploma in Animation and Multimedia (AIM).
Primarily interested in language, image and sound relationships to examine contemporary and popular consumer culture his work has been exhibited at The Centre for Contemporary Photography, Arts Victoria, The Project Space and Monash University. In 2001 he was the only Australian selected for The New Talent Competition at Milia in Cannes, France, one of the worlds largest and prestigious multimedia showcases for his CD_ROM work 'Memo'.
He has often been invited to speak about new media art and design at conferences and institutions, including Fusion -the digital program at The St Kilda Film Festival, The London College of Printings Multimedia Department, the Japanese Broadcasting Corporation - NHK and the Net Zapping Festival in France.
He is currently working as a print, web and interactive designer at the multimedia studio Drome.

results.name: Deborah Kelly
results.biography:
Deborah Kelly
b. 1962 Melbourne, Victoria
Lives mainly in Sydney & part time in Melbourne, works everywhere she can.

Deborah Kelly has been making socially engaged artwork since 1983. She was also a Creative Director of Australia's largest public interest communications company for 7 years. Her projects implicate broad audiences in the discourses of local & momentary histories, and seek to intervene into representation of place and privilege. Recent collaborative projects have included boat-people.org, graphic civil disobedience on refugees, mass actions on Aboriginal Land Rights, and the prize-winning public art project with Tina Fiveash "Hey, hetero!", which has been shown in Sydney, Adelaide, Melbourne and Wellington. She co-curated and conceived the exhibition / symposium / tactical media lab BORDERPANIC, a Performance Space/Museum of Contemporary Art/Next 5Minutes co-production in September 2002, with Zina Kaye. She has given public lectures and workshops around Australia and in San Francisco, Los Angeles and Ottawa. She was invited by Martha Rosler to a political artists' residency in Florida, USA, Jan- Feb 2002, and remains actively engaged in online collaborations with that crew.

Current projects include being commissioning editor/artist for It's Great to Be Straight: a critical anthology regarding heterosexuality for Pluto Press (forthcoming), boat people.org, TPV holder's legal project with Smash Racism, and working with Martha Rosler on a collaborative installation and poster series for the Utopia Station at the Venice Bienalle, 2003.

results.name: Shaun Gladwell

roles_in_work.title: Shaun Gladwell: excerpts from selected video works 2000-2002

results.biography:
Born 1972, lives and works in Sydney.
Gladwell completed an honours degree at Sydney College of the Arts, University of Sydney, and undertook postgraduate research with the College of Fine Arts, University of New South Wales. He was awarded the Samstag International Visual Arts Scholarship and conducted associate research at Goldsmiths College, University of London, in 2001-02. He has undertaken an Australia Council studio residency at the Cité Internationale des Arts, Paris and has exhibited widely in the past ten years throughout Australia and in the United States, Canada and Europe. He is a founding member of the Sydney-based artist collective Imperial Slacks.
